section.section:
In a case under this subtitle, a court shall appoint an attorney to represent a parent who:
has a disability that makes the parent incapable of effectively participating in the case; or
when the parent must decide whether to consent to adoption, is still a minor.
To determine whether a disability makes a parent incapable of effectively participating in a case, a court, on its own motion or on motion of a party, may order examination of the parent.

In a case under this subtitle, a court shall appoint an attorney to represent a prospective adoptee who:
has a disability that makes the prospective adoptee incapable of effectively participating in the case; and
when the prospective adoptee must decide whether to consent to adoption, is at least 10 years old.

To determine whether a disability makes a prospective adoptee incapable of effectively participating in a case, a court, on its own motion or on motion of a party, may order examination of the prospective adoptee.

text.section:
An attorney or firm:
may represent more than one party in a case under this subtitle only if the Maryland Lawyers' Rules of Professional Conduct allow; and
may not represent a prospective adoptive parent and parent in the same adoption case.
Counsel appointed under this section may be compensated for reasonable fees, as approved by the court.
